title: Hepatocellular Carcinoma in Cirrhosis
diagnosis_topic: Primary liver tumor arising in a cirrhotic liver
setup_script: A 58-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C and compensated cirrhosis presents for routine surveillance. Ultrasound detects a 2.5 cm lesion in segment VI of the liver. Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident reviews liver function tests
dynamic_flow.reply: Child-Pugh A (bilirubin 1.2 mg/dL, albumin 3.5 g/dL, INR 1.1, no ascites or encephalopathy).
Lesion shows arterial enhancement and washout in venous phase, meeting LI-RADS criteria for HCC.
For solitary tumor <3 cm and Child-Pugh A, consider surgical resection, radiofrequency ablation or transplantation depending on portal hypertension and performance status.
Endoscopy shows small varices; hepatic venous pressure gradient 9 mmHg (no significant portal hypertension).
Right segmentectomy planned with negative margins; patient counselled on risks.
Tumor may grow beyond Milan criteria precluding transplant.
Option for unresectable lesions or as bridge to transplant.
Milan criteria: single lesion 5 cm or up to three lesions all 3 cm with no vascular invasion.
Imaging and AFP every 3-6 months to detect recurrence.
Continues direct-acting antivirals for hepatitis C to reduce recurrence risk.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers underlying cirrhosis management
dynamic_flow.reply: Abstinence from alcohol, vaccination for hepatitis A/B, screening for esophageal varices.
Explain prognosis, potential for recurrence and importance of adherence to surveillance.

critical_decision_points: Interpretation of imaging criteria for hepatocellular carcinoma
Assessment of liver function and portal hypertension to guide therapy
Selection of appropriate treatment modality (resection, ablation, transplantation, TACE)
Understanding Milan criteria and timing of therapy
Postoperative and long-term surveillance and management of underlying liver disease
